reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before anything else, let me explain the game. You own a kingdom. Why? Who knows. You build stuff (taverns, shops, barracks, etc.) in a large-ish grid of grass and trees. You attract people into your kingdom, in hopes of them buying some stuff from your shops, like your average tycoon, although as of yet it is a very small focus. The big focus is on quests. You send your heroes on certain types of quests (rescue, vanquish, deliver, etc.) in certain other kingdoms. You allot some points to certain categories, and they're on their way. Thats pretty much it. Build more, quest more. Thats kind of all it is now. Now on with the rating. First of all, if I could rate this game N/A, I would. This game is simply unstable. There are many many bugs and imbalances. The developer himself said the game cost almost nothing to make, so I truly think the game would have been shed in a far better light if he waited to release it on early access. Although it is on the right track, its hard to recommend it as it is. Here is a pros and cons list, with that out of the way:

Cons:
Unbalanced
Buggy
Sensory-depriving color pallette, nothing but green and brown and gold highlights the whole game.
Somewhat repetative quests, with sliders that seem to do nothing (unlike the ever-important sliders in GDT) EDIT: Sliders are now gone, and are replaced with... nothing? Now its worse than before, but not stealing something anymore.
Slow progression, esp. in building.
Once money (sorry, 'gold') goes below 0, its game over. No exceptions or anything, just a game over screen.
Heros slowly die, with no apparent way to heal them. You even get a healing potion store, but not for them I guess. EDIT: This is aparently now fixed
Klunky UI
(keep in mind that almost all of these cons are things that can very easily be fixed by tweaking some numbers and code, so its up to the developer to make things right, for me atleast.)

Pros:
Interesting and unique graphics (though they could still use quite a bit of work)
Despite monotony, still quite fun.
Things to research,
Shops to run,
Not much else to say.

I recommend this game because it is absolutely on the right track. If everything goes as it is, this game will be good. I can't disrecommend this game because of unforseen bugs and unbalances. While the developer should have released it a bit later, he very well might not have gotten any playtesters, therefore not being able to find any of those bugs or unbalances. The core game is fun, and thats all I'm looking for. So overall, I'm cutting this game some slack. I'll probably only play it briefly after the large updates every few weeks or so. The developer very honestly says he will work as hard as he can to finish this game, but anything can happen to one lone developer. A caring, involved developer like this is what this game needs to be fixed. I just hope he will. As of now, the current update, wait to buy, but you eventually should.

reviewText:
RPG Tycoon - Review
Gameplay:
This game features two different aspects (RPG and Tycoon, duh), which are brought together in a rather interesting, but initially confusing way. Basically half of the game happens in text boxes.
You manage a kingdom, build it, take care of your people (your followers) and expand by meeting the needs of both your followers and your heroes.
Heroes bring in the aspect of RPG: You use the heroes to gain gold, experience, supplies and reputation all around, by sending them on quests. These quests do have direct effects on your kingdom, but in terms of gameplay are basically a few textboxes and a progress bar. It basically brings in another aspect of management, next to the management of income, followers and overall expansion.
The game was very confusing in the beginning, since you need to figure out how much you actually spend on working on your kingdom and how much you invest into your heroes and their quests.
There is a big repertory on buildings and quests, so one is faced with a lot of decisions.
The Tycoon part in general is filled with neat sprites, whilst the RPG part is pretty basic, yet it plays a big role in the development of your kingdom.

The game also features quite a lot of bugs, which, for a full-release title, certainly is a big down.

Pros:
+The aspect of kingdom-management has been very well designed
+Long lasting gameplay
+Full workshop support

Cons:
-The RPG aspect of the game is textbased and very basic
-Bugs

Conclusion:
The game seems to be in a strange harmony, with the graphic based kingdom management, and the text based quests, where you need to find the balance between these two aspects to be successful on your journey.
Since this game is already full-release I can not ignore the bugs and they therefore also will be part of the final score:
5/10 - in its current state.

Early Access Review

I've had this game for awhile now. Its one of those games that I want to love, but just can't.

Here are a few reasons why...
1. Stability is an issue even now, almost a year after Early Access opened. Funny thing is: stability has actually gotten worse
2. The  UI is terrible. Confusing and counter-intuitive, you'll likely find yourself clicking around in menus trying to find things for several minutes
3. The game is largely all dicerolls. Its unclear how to influence your odds
4, Missions are arbitrary and pointless. There is no reason to read the text. It doesn't even tell a cohesive story
5. Its not clear what the game is about. Is it about hero management or city building? And what's the deal with neighboring towns (some you're competing against, and some you're just visiting). It doesn't seem like the game-maker has a single vision for the game, but rather has a few visions for a few different games and kinda just taped them together.

At the time of writing this, the game isn't worth your money (August 8, 2015). However it *is* still early access, so I might have to modify these words eventually.

I particularly am impressed with the amount of new things a hero can do while another does the generic questing. The settlements have now become far more interactive, the shops serve more purpose than just money farming, and the inventory system now seems much more efficient at relating to the player what exactly they have and what it is good for. There are quite a few things left for me to really explore in this game, however it does seem familiar to another game by Kairosoft which I also loved called Dungeon Village, but even so this game is quickly surpassing that in terms of activities and gameplay especially the questing which allows you to choose your type of destiny instead of just accepting what there is already.

for my obligatory rant however, I must say that the interface and specifically the ability to click on a specific object like a dirt road to delete resulted in my accidentally deleting an accessory shop, I would ask that with the opacity option maybe a more refined targetting with my cursor is desired. Also another petpeeve i've developed is with the arbitrary award system at the end of the year. In dungeon village the village and its heros in particular are awarded medals which are actual items that can be used to improve a hero's stats across the board. I'm not suggesting that exact thing but I would prefer something other than numbers and letters at the end of the year as this just does not add anything special to the game for me in particular. Lastly, and remember I have not played through the entire game since the last update but I feel as though the random events could be more than just global modifiers maybe something more interactive or under your control or the option to attempt to control the event would be preferable than just accepting the event as is. I suggest maybe also adding something similar to the dice roll system from epic quests allowing your heros to not only quest for settlements but to have the chance to maybe protect, improve, prevent, etc options for a global modifier event. Anyway I will be returning to play this after work, and the game as it has now become and currently is, worthy of purchase and worthy of your playtime. I don't know the developer or what he is working with but I saw a pile of crap spread on an empty canvas become a beautiful painting that still needs a slight touch up. Good work man and please continue to do your best and follow your own vision more so than the people who make suggestions because in the end they bought your game because of your decisions and visions and alot of developers seem to bow down to every crappy suggestion that sounds good on paper but damages the core gameplay that originally attracted that same person who made the suggestion to the game in the first place. tl;dr keep doing your own thing, but stay open minded to suggestions that may still be useful or an improvement to your vision.

reviewText: This comes down to early access as a concept. The idea is to support very small indie developers with a great concept that you would like to see developed. There are countless articles in the gaming press about how studios are taking less and less chances since games cost so much to make. This means fewer new IPs or game series and the first genres to suffer are the niches like management/tycoon/sim. This is because it's a smaller audience and a group that by nature waits for sales and opportunities to buy games(trained to look for a bargain by the very games that suffer due to this emotional IQ) for less. If you want games like this your only chance is to continue to support titles like this one in Early Access. To be honest, half will turn out as garbage. A 1/4 will be an outright waste. Another 1/4 though will turn out to be a gem that guides the genre for the next few years and that's worth taking chances. For a genre that simulates business you need to follow the real guideline which is perseverence in the face of staggering odds. 9/10 new businesses fail(false but often quoted stat) and that should roughly guide you when buying EA titles in this genre. You don't avoid starting a business because your chances are small. In fact the reason you keep going is because that eventual success is worth it.\n\nIs this game great...no. However, it has good ideas and flawed execution. Common to EA and this genre. You should buy it to experience it's better mechanics and ideas. You should buy it to show the developers that there is still a market for this type of game. You should buy it to keep this developer making games. His next will be better than this. Eventually he could make the gold standard tycoon game. If you don't support it because it's not perfect then you guarantee the chances of playing a great management game go down for all of us. That's the simple fact.

reviewText:
Let me start off with this, this game is really nice. I've been playing nonstop for the past few hours now and it's a really smooth playing game. There is a little learning curve(bankrupted my first kingdom) but once you get used to it, it's not hard.

I'll start with my first impressions. There is a tutorial that I'm guessing helps you through it(I skipped it and learned by mistake). The game starts off kinda tedious because you only have a few quick quests you can do at the start and you just cycle through all 5 until you get a few more. You luckily don't have to remember what works best for each quest because it has a history feature which shows what goes with what. The art style reminds me of tycoon type games back in the 90s and early 2000s. The UI is nice and easy to understand with tooltips telling you what each button does. I noticed a few typos but nothing a hotfix can't remedy.

After a few hours the game starts to pick up because you can now start what are called Epic Quests. Epic Quests are quests that take 2 or more heroes to start. These quests allow you to get more supplies and quick quests as well as other valuable items like weapons and armor. You don't need to do epic quests just to get more quick quests once you unlock the library(I think kingdom level 3) you can research all types of things from lower maintenance costs for your buildings to more followers per settlement.

Don't get me started on modding this game. It's one of the easiest games to mod. First off everything is shown in pretty much plain text(XML) and they have a whole page of the site to help with modding the game. Let's say you want to mod the UI to have a few different textures(I completely changed the color of the UI to green, which you can get on the workshop) all you have to do is go into the UI.png spritesheet change the text you want and next time you load the game it's changed. I recommend making the mod in a folder in the mods folder to make disabling and enabling them easier. Adding quests and heroes is also very easy by just adding a new line to the heroes.xml.

Pros:
- Easy to use interface
- Modding support
- Self-explanatory UI and functions
- 90s and early 2000s tycoon nostalgia look and feel

Cons:
- Few bugs
- Little grindy

Rating:
9.5/10

Edit: The customer support is amazing. The new update(1.0.6) broke my save but the dev is already pushing out a fix for it and it's only been like an hour. Not only that but he also helped me through any help I needed for modding.

Early Access Review

March 20th 2015 Update:
So its been nearly 6 months and I thought that this is a Early Access game and 6 months should be a nice distance of time for upgrading, updating and fixing, and I can say that RPG Tycoon has seriously updated since its August 2014 edition.
So what has upgraded the game?
In my original review, I had said little but had pointed out that the game was broke as, and now it feels nice and smooth and runs perfectly, so far I have come across some little glitches, but none were too game breaking.
Next is about how the game was originally a borefest, and it was, there was 0 to do, and now there is a lot of stuff to  do, and it feels like a true tycoon game unlike the original, and that is what makes it great now, it is a game worth time, which won't get boring in about 1 hour. And well there is still a lot of room for upgrades with that, as it shows, there is so much potential that is showing now, and hopefully it can use the rest of the time it has in early access perfectly.
Last of all is how it has upgraded so well in its looks and navigation, unlike its original version which had a clunky and broken menu and lacked anything, it now added stuff which are needed, now there is some options still to be added but the important ones are  there, which is great. And also the game is actually possible to navigate, at first it took me about 4 minutes to get into the game, which was a let down at that, but now it is fixed, and takes mere seconds, even less at that, and its worth it.
Now with all the positives, the game still does have problems, it does feel that is lacks buildings and size, and after a bit I felt that this stuff could've been added when after all this was a problem for people, though I understand that fixing the game was a big thing needed.

So is  it worth buying RPG Tycoon at the moment?
Yes it is!
Over the course of 6 months this game has came from being a cluggy bit of a mess to a true and great tycoon game, which is worth £5, after all it goes to help the dev upgrade.
8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brief summary of beta version of RPG Tycoon- Game is very buggy as warned, looks very promising but needs to take some pages from successful GameDev Tycoon.

Elongated breakdown-

Opened up my Store on steam to see this little Number pop up! Well hello little number maybe a 1 or even a lil .5. Nonetheless this game was there and as I really have enjoyed playing GameDevTycoon. I think this game can really learn a few things from Gamedev...

Graphics- The graphics are good and very reminiscent of old school Runescape. Which plays in very well into the game.

Sliders- The sliders don't make much sense and is very vague.. Also are very cumbersome and need some better sound effects the default Window sound is very unappealing.

Knowledge in Game- When you begin the game you are very overwhelmed and yet underwhelmed. You get some basic knowledge and are confused at the same time. You have no idea about what is working within the quests (like within the sliders and what works with what also point allocation).

Point allocation- The game has a bug where you can adjust the top portion of the allocation system by minusing them and have it return next quest with the points still remaining where you added them last time.

Money- I had no idea you lost the game when you ran out of money and so I ended the game within 2 mins by trying to build my city in more and adding roads.. To only have the game be all like you suck GG.

Visitors-Their bubbles of text get stuck behind buildings and cannot be read.

Quests and making money- NOOO Clue how to make good money, felt like I’m just waiting for my quests tooooo sllllooowwwwllllyyyy produce the little change each time.. Perhaps needs to be upped a bit? or I'm just a bit inpatient, who knows probably the second. The quests also need to be clearer and more feedback is needed and perhaps a memory system again similar to GameDev...

UI- is very clear and clean but needs some better animations and sound effects. Hopefully they will add in better tutorials and make the game easier to jump in.

Questing- Please make the UI more fun and clear when your hero is on a quest. You get no idea why points are getting added into the certain places.

As I said before game looks great, shows a lot of promise and I can't wait for it to be finished to really log in some hours. I hope they change the music to something a lil catchier, add in some better sound effects, update the UI a bit more, and clean up the game all around to be honest. Will play more, look forward to the full release.


Thanks for reading my rant. (PS: I’ve only spent a few times on this game so read my review with that in mind)

Version 0.61 (2hrs);
On this new patch, many negative things about the 0.6 update have been solved. There are of course good and bad points to the game, however with most of the bad ones gone; the game has become very enjoyable. I would now happily recommend the game, just read about the current bugs beforehand so you can really enjoy the wonderful game of RPG Tycoon.
I shall not detail you with what has been fixed as you should no longer have those issues, and so I have listed the bugs and errors that I encountered while playing this time around.

Minor Isues;
1) Without any load files, the load screen shows a fourth place that is partially outside the box, very minor but I like neatness
2) Maybe I did not realise how I was playing but suddenly my kingdom had 1% attraction and all three settlement’s had minimal to no “likeness”. This caused me to resort to spamming my kingdom with decorations just to keep a solid income.
3) Missing sprites when I once tried to use “bread” on a hero, clicking out and clicking back in solved this.
4) A few text bugs and issues when viewing your heroes
5) When you find multiple items with the same image, you can see the additional text of the first one, but not the second, this however is only for this moment and can be viewed normally in your inventory
6) Once when my main hero (The first to hire) went into the “Potion Store” and was finished, his name and a bar was still there above the shop, the hero could do all actions normally and this text issue only disappeared when he returned into the same shop (a few in-game years later)

Major Issues;
1) Manually saved and loaded the save file in the second slot (Not Auto-Save), my first 2 heroes that were the quest leaders had returned instantly along with the 2 other heroes that were on the “Epic Quest”, however I could no longer select to do either the “Quick Quest” or “Epic Quest” as I believe the system thinks that they are still on this quest, however with no quest bar at the bottom it could not be fixed. This was a major problem so a long time in-game later I saved it manually again, and loaded it, the issue was fixed, however by then I fired my heroes.
All remaining issues were found after the second loading.
2) The villainy tracker had all reset, as well the bounty level had reset.
3) The first of each quest type rewarded me with 0 Gold and 0 Followers, each quest after this was normal.
4) One time my hero just never returned from an “Epic Quest”
5) Lag started to occur quite a lot.
6) Upon saving and leaving the game, the title screen had turned black, except from a centre square in the screen big enough to see the game was still running, however I could not click on any buttons as they were inside the black screen. reviewText:
Early Access Review

**********Updated 2/10/2015**********

Below you'll see my previous reviews, I'm keeping them there as the review grows, so that any who are interested can see the progress made.

Just like last time, I'll list off bugs first:
1: Whenever two heroes rest in the same building, one of them will get locked in that building, and will never come out. the only way to get that hero back, is to sack them, watch their avatar leave the town and then rehire them.
2: Various mispellings, if those even count as bugs.
3: That's it, I haven't encountered any other bugs lately.

Btw, for a TL;DR version, scroll to the bottom, just before the next updated line.

So how is the game different now?
Quick Quests now have a unique gameplay to them, that I haven't played in another tycoon game.

First you select a town, then you select a quest type, after selecting that quest type, you have a screen of supplies, the supply screen is what I can assume the influences from Game Dev Tycoon turned into, and it adapts well.
You see, each town requires different supplies on different quests, so even if you do a Raider quest in town A, and get all 6 supplies matched in their correct slots, that doesn't mean it'll be the same way in town B.
You also do not get all the supplies straight off the bat, while I can't say I like having those supplies withheld, it makes for a lot of replayability as you try and earn all the supplies, so it ends up being pretty damn enjoyable.

The Epic quests however feel lacking in comparison to the quick quests, and I think they could really utilise their own unique gameplay, I already see evidence of how this could be achieved with the mid quest story prompts, but I'd like to see something at the start, similar to quick quest's preparation stage, but unique.

I don't understand the bounties very well at the moment, I searched for a villain and afterward that quest line became unaccessible.

One of my major complaints in the previous versions was the lack of feedback, this has been corrected and there's now a lot of information on the screen, The hud can feel a bit encumbering, I'd like to either see the hud size be controllable in the options, but that wouldn't need to be an exact option, many other solutions would work.

The top left window can be minimized but others can not. however, the bottom left one, shouldn't be able to be minimized, I'd rather see it fade into the background when a target isn't selected. I'd also like to see the bottom left window only function when a target is clicked instead of hovered over.
The top right information feed, feels rather rough, the messages don't need to stay for long and could actually be automatically deleted for you, I'm sure though that the developer is looking at this, with his own solution in mind.
The rest of the hud however, is well designed, pleasing to the eyes and gives relevant information.

The research is good, but feels like it lacks a lot of research, and I'd like to see it play a second role.

The town management is coming along nicely, and while playing, I actually thought that it was possible to create a self sustaining town, that does not rely on the funds from your heroes.
I would like to see that be a thing, a self sustaining town, but I'd rather see it as a possible avenue for development in the game that you have to specifically pursue, and not an eventuality that every playthrough will lead to.


TL;DR:
The game is now at a playable stage, and the game finally has a strong foundation to fall back on, that doesn't take too heavily from other games.
It's enjoyable, and in the playthrough that lead to this updated review, I actually sunk a few hours into it all at once.

Rating:
What it is: 6.5/10
What it could be: 9/10

I'm excited to see the end product when it leaves early access, I believe it'd net a 7.5/10 at this rate.

tl;dr version: game still in alpha (incomplete, buggy), but now in an acceptable state as far as early access games go.

edit 10/17/15 review update

When I first got RPG Tycoon many moons ago, it was just awful. One of those early access games so early in development, it felt like a gyp. It was like that for quite some time up until roughly the second half of 2015. That's when the developer finally got serious working on his game. I've seen RPG Tycoon grow and mature over time to a point where it is now showing promise and potential to be a decent albiet simple and crude management simulator.

In my previous review, I  did not recommend due to how unstable it was and a memory leak that slowed the game down so much it became unplayable.

Since then, those two issues are gone. I now recommend RPG Tycoon!

Well, as an alpha anyway.

RPG Tycoon is far from complete. Some features are still obviously being worked on. There are still annoying bugs you can't avoid while playing. Game is in need of balance tweaks. Loading save games still has a high risk of causing something to glitch out. Visitors still tend to get frozen in place and never leave.

But the game is now in a state that I can call playable. Its pretty okay for what it is too.

Basically if you've been eyeballing this game thinking about buying it, I'd say its safe to buy now. The developer is now supporting their game and updates are churning out more frequently. But, obviously, if you're one of those types who can't stand unfinished/buggy games steer clear for the time being. RPG Tycoon has a long way to go still.

reviewText:
I have such a love-hate relatoinship with this game right now. I'll start with the bad.

Yes people have said bugs, but what bugs? Let me mention my two most annoying ones.
1. Deleted/messed up save files. I'll go back in to play and I will be pushed back by a lot of progress and I'll forget how I got to where I'd been so I just start over which is really annoying after the 5th time. The most recent occurence could have been because the game updated, not sure.
2. I would click on a character and click on their name and a box would come up, but I couldn't get rid of it and I would have to close out of the game and lose my progress.

In addition to this it does bother me a bit that the difficulty curve on epic quests is a bit odd but whatever.

Now on to the good!

I first purchased this game I think last year? Not sure exactly. But a ton of things have been improved since then making things more logical, giving more options, and I love all of the equipment and items. Really it's becoming a thorough game.

I think that this game has a ton of potential but it's still not perfect. I really suggest that anyone try this out, especially those who like time management, rpg mechanics, tycoon games (obviously), or anyone with some free time on their hands. The price is worth it.
